english: remote areas; territory (early form of 鄙)

etymology.description: semantic: 囗 ‘city boundary’ + 㐭 ‘granary’; original form of 鄙.
etymology.interpretation: Enclosure for a city boundary pairs with a granary to picture a storehouse located beyond the walls, evoking the outskirts or countryside. By extension it came to mean the borderland or remote areas, and was later standardized as 鄙.

examples.chinese: 将军奉命巡边，远至啚地(將軍奉命巡邊，遠至啚地)。
examples.pinyin: Jiāng jūn fèng mìng xún biān, yuǎn zhì bǐ dì.
examples.english: The general was ordered to patrol the borders, reaching the remote outlands.

examples.chinese: 乡民在啚地屯粮，以备荒年(鄉民在啚地屯糧，以備荒年)。
examples.pinyin: Xiāng mín zài bǐ dì tún liáng, yǐ bèi huāng nián.
examples.english: Villagers stockpiled grain in the outlands to prepare for years of famine.

examples.chinese: 古籍记载，此处本为啚，后并入郡县(古籍記載，此處本為啚，後併入郡縣)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔ jí jì zǎi, cǐ chù běn wéi bǐ, hòu bìng rù jùn xiàn.
examples.english: Ancient records note that this place was once the borderland, later incorporated into a commandery and county.
